budgeting_tips.tip: Aim to save 3-6 months of expenses in an easily accessible account
Apply for financial aid and scholarships before taking student loans
Start with a secured credit card and always pay on time to build credit history
Take advantage of employer 401(k) matching - it's free money
Maximize contributions to tax-advantaged accounts like 401(k) and IRA
Pay off high-interest debt first (avalanche method) to save on interest

investment_basics.explanation: Don't put all your eggs in one basket - spread investments across different asset classes
Invest a fixed amount regularly regardless of market conditions to reduce timing risk
Low-cost funds that track market indexes, providing broad diversification
Earning interest on both principal and previously earned interest - time is your friend

common_mistakes.consequence: Being forced to use credit cards or loans for unexpected expenses
common_mistakes.solution: Start with $500-1000 emergency fund, then build to 3-6 months expenses

common_mistakes.mistake: Paying only minimum on credit cards
common_mistakes.consequence: Paying significantly more in interest over time
common_mistakes.solution: Pay more than minimum, focus on high-interest debt first

common_mistakes.consequence: Missing out on free money from employer
common_mistakes.solution: Contribute at least enough to get full employer match

common_mistakes.consequence: Missing out on long-term gains, emotional investing decisions
common_mistakes.solution: Use dollar-cost averaging and stick to long-term investment plan
